channel.title: California
channel.description: California news and features from the Los Angeles Times.

item.title: Brush fire burns Bolsa Chica wetlands in Huntington Beach
item.dc:creator: Laura Newberry
item.description: Blaze near Pacific Coast Highway triggers voluntary evacuation of Brightwater neighborhood.
item.content:encoded: Blaze near Pacific Coast Highway triggers voluntary evacuation of Brightwater neighborhood.

media:content.media:description: Firefighters on Sunday quickly brought under control most of a small brush fire that burned in the Bolsa Chica wetlands area of Huntington Beach.

item.title: Seven hurt, four arrested in scuffle between police and protesters in downtown L.A.
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: Demonstrators had organized the actions in response to federal agents being sent to Portland, Ore., to put down nightly protests that began two months ago following the killing of George Floyd by Minneapolis police.
item.content:encoded: Demonstrators had organized the actions in response to federal agents being sent to Portland, Ore., to put down nightly protests that began two months ago following the killing of George Floyd by Minneapolis police.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JULY 25, 2020. Protesters link arms and face off against the LAPD in front of L.A. City Hall during a Refuse Fascism demonstration on Saturday, July 25, 2020. (Luis Sinco / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Even with incomplete data, L.A. County records 1,703 new coronavirus cases and 10 related deaths
item.dc:creator: Joseph Serna
item.description: L.A. County officials say state lab data is incomplete and six hospitals did not provide information
item.content:encoded: L.A. County officials say state lab data is incomplete and six hospitals did not provide information

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA -- MARCH 10, 2020: Dr. Barbara Ferrer is the director of the Los Angeles County Department of Public Health. She gives her daily update on Tuesday. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Arrest made in fatal shooting of teenage girl in Hollywood
item.dc:creator: Joseph Serna
item.description: An arrest has been made in the killing of a girl at the corner of Hollywood Boulevard and Highland Avenue early Sunday.
item.content:encoded: An arrest has been made in the killing of a girl at the corner of Hollywood Boulevard and Highland Avenue early Sunday.

item.title: They made a home under L.A.'s freeways. But soon they could be forced to move
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Oreskes
item.description: A judge ordered officials to provide space in shelters or alternative housing for homeless residents living near freeways. But where will they go?
item.content:encoded: A judge ordered officials to provide space in shelters or alternative housing for homeless residents living near freeways. But where will they go?

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JULY 08, 2020 - - Kim M. and her dog Dee-O-G live homeless under the Santa Monica freeway along Venice Blvd. in Los Angeles on July 8, 2020. The city and county of Los Angeles plan to move people from the freeways. U.S. District Judge David O. Carter passed a landmark court order banning homeless encampments from under and along Los Angeles freeways. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Outdoor religious gatherings draw warnings and rebukes from health officials
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth, Cindy Chang
item.description: From Orange County to Northern California, people continue to gather for large outdoor religious ceremonies without following rules to slow the spread of the coronavirus, prompting stern reprimands from public health officials.
item.content:encoded: From Orange County to Northern California, people continue to gather for large outdoor religious ceremonies without following rules to slow the spread of the coronavirus, prompting stern reprimands from public health officials.

media:content.media:description: Hundreds gathered for the weekly Saturate OC worship event held north of the pier in Huntington Beach, on Friday, July 10, 2020.

item.title: 'Open today, closed tomorrow' is the new normal for hair, nail salons due to coronavirus
item.dc:creator: Anh Do
item.description: "Open today, closed tomorrow" is the revised normal for hair and nail salons struggling to stay afloat, faced with coronavirus.
item.content:encoded: "Open today, closed tomorrow" is the revised normal for hair and nail salons struggling to stay afloat, faced with coronavirus.

media:content.media:description: FOUNTAIN VALLEY, CA - JULY 22: Travis Vu cuts a client's hair in one of two chairs outdoors in front of his TravisVu The Salon in Fountain Valley, as mandated Monday by Gov. Newsom. Vu said he could never have imagined having to move his salon outdoors to do business, but is doing his best to keep his business afloat and four employees working. He and his employees has had to cut their client load by half due to the Governor's coronavirus restrictions. Photo taken Wednesday, July 22, 2020. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: By easing its bar exam score, will California produce more Black and Latino lawyers?
item.dc:creator: Maura Dolan
item.description: Law school deans in California clamored for years to reduce the bar exam's passing score. When the pandemic hit, the California Supreme Court acted.
item.content:encoded: Law school deans in California clamored for years to reduce the bar exam's passing score. When the pandemic hit, the California Supreme Court acted.

media:content.media:description: Law students take a practice California State Bar Exam at the University of California at Berkeley campus.

item.title: How Latino dads are using TikTok to connect with their children
item.dc:creator: TomÃ¡s Mier
item.description: Charli D'Amelio who? These dads are blasting to the top of Latinos' For You Pages with #mexicandadsbelike and other relatable hashtags.
item.content:encoded: Charli D'Amelio who? These dads are blasting to the top of Latinos' For You Pages with #mexicandadsbelike and other relatable hashtags.

media:content.media:description: SANTA ANA, CA - JULY 22, 2020: Eveli Paz videotapes her father-in-law Genaro Rangel and sister-in-law Wendy Rangel using the TikTok app while they dance to Latin music for a new fad called Latino Papas on July 22, 2020 in Santa Ana, California. The Rangels are two TikTokkers who've gone viral on the app several times for silly videos.(Gina Ferazzi / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Column: They're fed up with the 'tyranny' of face masks. But Portland? That's about 'law and order'
item.dc:creator: Erika D. Smith
item.description: Federal agents in Portland are violating protesters' civil rights. But government-overreach hating conservatives say it's "law and order," not "tyranny."
item.content:encoded: Federal agents in Portland are violating protesters' civil rights. But government-overreach hating conservatives say it's "law and order," not "tyranny."

media:content.media:description: People attend the United We Stand rally in Sacramento on July 25, 2020.
media:content.media:credit: Erika D. Smith/ Los Angeles Times

item.title: Los Angeles firefighter dies from complications of COVID-19

item.content:encoded: Firefighter-paramedic Jose J. Perez, a victim of COVID, was 44 and had been with the LAFD for more than 16 years, officials said.

item.title: L.A. County reports more than 3,600 new coronavirus cases and 53 related deaths
item.dc:creator: Paloma Esquivel
item.description: L.A. County health officials on Saturday reported 3,628 new COVID-19 cases and 53 more related deaths, high numbers that in part reflect reporting delays in the state's electronic laboratory system.
item.content:encoded: L.A. County health officials on Saturday reported 3,628 new COVID-19 cases and 53 more related deaths, high numbers that in part reflect reporting delays in the state's electronic laboratory system.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JULY 08: EMT Miriam Yanez delivers the testing kit to drivers during drive through Coronavirus Covid-19 testing in LA County at the Charles R. Drew University of Medicine and Science in South Los Angeles on July 8, 2020 as California records its highest single-day coronavirus death toll with 149 fatalities reported. The Charles R. Drew University site has tested a large number of people from racial and ethnic minority groups that are at higher risk for poor outcomes and complications from COVID-19. Drew University on Wednesday, July 8, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Coronavirus cases seep into the ranks of Newport Beach first responders
item.dc:creator: Hillary Davis
item.description: Newport Beach firefighters and lifeguards are among the 33,358 who have tested positive for the coronavirus in Orange County.
item.content:encoded: Newport Beach firefighters and lifeguards are among the 33,358 who have tested positive for the coronavirus in Orange County.

media:content.media:description: A city lifeguard keeps an eye on the few people on the beach next to the Balboa Pier in Newport Beach on Wednesday, May 6, 2020. The city partially opened the beaches under an "active recreational use" plan approved today by State officials.

item.title: Firefighters gain ground on Lassen County blazes
item.dc:creator: Cindy Chang
item.description: In Northern California, Cal Fire said Saturday that the Gold fire was 40% contained and the Hog fire 45% contained.
item.content:encoded: In Northern California, Cal Fire said Saturday that the Gold fire was 40% contained and the Hog fire 45% contained.

media:content.media:description: Smoke from the Hog Fire is seen from Highway 36 west of Susanville, California, on Sunday, July 19, 2020. Mandatory evacuations are in effect for the Hog Fire which has grown to 9 square miles (23 square kilometers) in Lassen County. Cal Fire says about 170 structures are threatened.(Anjeanette Damon/The Reno Gazette-Journal via AP)

item.title: Large outdoor religious gathering draws ire of officials in Redding
item.dc:creator: Cindy Chang
item.description: Videos of the July 22 gathering show people crowded together with no coronavirus masks, waving their hands in the air and singing songs of praise.
item.content:encoded: Videos of the July 22 gathering show people crowded together with no coronavirus masks, waving their hands in the air and singing songs of praise.

media:content.media:description: ** ADVANCE FOR THE WEEKEND OF JULY, 3-4 **The Sun Dial Bridge is seen from the Sacramento River, Monday, June 28, 2004, in Redding, Calif. The 700-foot-long, 23-foot-wide footbridge was designed by world-famous architect, engineer and artist Santiago Calatrava, who also designed the Olympic Sports Complex for the Athens 2004 Summer Games. (AP Photo/Ben Margot)

item.title: A boy walks to a corner store and is shot in the chest. 'I don't think we could ever heal'
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: Otis Williams, 14, was shot to death in South L.A. this month. He wasn't a gang member. A suspect or motive is unknown, Sheriff's Lt. Derrick Alfred said.
item.content:encoded: Otis Williams, 14, was shot to death in South L.A. this month. He wasn't a gang member. A suspect or motive is unknown, Sheriff's Lt. Derrick Alfred said.

media:content.media:description: Otis Williams, 14, was shot to death in South L.A. earlier this month. He was not a gang member and detectives have yet to identify any suspects or a motive, Sheriff's Lt. Derrick Alfred said.

item.title: Column: Mexican-American's Dilemma: He's Unfit in Either Language
item.dc:creator: Ruben Salazar

item.title: Irvine mayor who blocked resident on Facebook is accused of violating 1st Amendment
item.dc:creator: Ben Brazil
item.description: Suit claims Irvine's mayor violated a resident's 1st Amendment rights when she blocked him from a Facebook discussion on police brutality and racism.
item.content:encoded: Suit claims Irvine's mayor violated a resident's 1st Amendment rights when she blocked him from a Facebook discussion on police brutality and racism.

media:content.media:description: Irvine Councilwoman Christina Shea placed an item on the council's Feb. 23 agenda to consider a citywide movement toward organic pesticides.

item.title: A COVID-19 death renews questions of responsibility of Uber and Lyft to drivers
item.dc:creator: Joshua Emerson Smith
item.description: Uber and Lyft drivers say the COVID-19 pandemic has them facing dangerous working conditions as they try to make ends meet.
item.content:encoded: Uber and Lyft drivers say the COVID-19 pandemic has them facing dangerous working conditions as they try to make ends meet.

media:content.media:description: Chuck Beckner poses for a photo with a picture of his mother and niece at his home on July 17, 2020 in El Cajon, California. Beckner's mother Billy Sue Matcke, whose name is tattooed on his chest (tattoo seen in photo) died of COVID-19 shortly after going back to work as an Uber and Lyft driver. Unrelated to the story, his niece Summer Ellen "Elle" Tudor (young girl in photo) has also passed.
media:content.media:credit: Eduardo Contreras / The San Diego Union-Tribune

item.title: Column: He had a box cutter, ignored commands, and a cop shot him six times. Were there better options?
item.dc:creator: Steve Lopez
item.description: She's a young LAPD officer, a gun-slinging social media hot shot, and she has defenders and critics
item.content:encoded: She's a young LAPD officer, a gun-slinging social media hot shot, and she has defenders and critics

media:content.media:description: Toni McBride, LAPD officer, was featured on the BLUE PRESS cover, Issue 336, June 2020 catalog, published by Dillion Precision Products, Inc. The Blue Press catalog contains articles about the shooting sports, firearms, reloading equipment, and other related topics. Credit: Dillion Precision Products, Inc.

item.title: This county knew coronavirus could ravage its farmworkers. Why didn't officials stop it?
item.dc:creator: Anita Chabria
item.description: Up to 70% of new cases of coronavirus in California's fertile San Joaquin Valley may be Latino workers, but advocates say they lack testing and access to care.
item.content:encoded: Up to 70% of new cases of coronavirus in California's fertile San Joaquin Valley may be Latino workers, but advocates say they lack testing and access to care.

media:content.media:description: Farmworkers weed a tomato field in French Camp, California on July 24, 2020. More than 70% of new cases of coronavirus in California's fertile San Joaquin valley are Latino workers, but advocates say they lack testing and access to care.

item.title: Pilot of small plane killed in Kern County crash
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller
item.description: The pilot of small plane was killed in a crash in Kern County on Friday, officials said.
item.content:encoded: The pilot of small plane was killed in a crash in Kern County on Friday, officials said.

item.title: Column: Chicanos Would Find Identity Before Coalition With Blacks
item.dc:creator: Ruben Salazar
item.description: Mexicans and Negroes are learning that they must know each other better if their differences are not to help those who would like to kill the civil rights movement.
item.content:encoded: Mexicans and Negroes are learning that they must know each other better if their differences are not to help those who would like to kill the civil rights movement.

item.title: Bat in Anaheim tests positive for rabies
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller
item.description: A bat found in front of an AT&T store in Anaheim last weekend has tested positive for rabies, Orange County officials announced Friday.
item.content:encoded: A bat found in front of an AT&T store in Anaheim last weekend has tested positive for rabies, Orange County officials announced Friday.

media:content.media:description: A man bitten by a vampire bite later died of rabies in the first such reported case in the U.S.

item.title: Garcetti loosens banner restrictions after cafe gets fined for 'we're open' sign
item.dc:creator: Jake Sheridan
item.description: Crave Cafe Studio City was fined $356 for a sign that read 'open for take-out and delivery.' L.A. Mayor Eric Garcetti changed rules and rescinded the fine Friday.
item.content:encoded: Crave Cafe Studio City was fined $356 for a sign that read 'open for take-out and delivery.' L.A. Mayor Eric Garcetti changed rules and rescinded the fine Friday.

media:content.media:description: STUDIO CITY, CA - JULY 24: Crave Cafe is photographed on Friday, July 24, 2020 in Studio City, CA. The business was issued a fine for $356 for putting up a sign that read "Open for take-out and delivery" without permission. The business is already struggling intensely because of the coronavirus. It's family owned and still operating, but they've had to lay off nearly two dozen employees. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A. County reports 1,900 more coronavirus cases and 44 additional deaths
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller
item.description: Los Angeles County on Friday reported more than 1,900 additional cases and 44 new deaths related to the coronavirus.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles County on Friday reported more than 1,900 additional cases and 44 new deaths related to the coronavirus.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JULY 24: Luis Ortiz, a Life Agent with Continental Funeral Home, released doves at the conclusion of a press conference with Los Angeles area funeral home owners and workers, in front of the California Secretary of State offices, in downtown Los Angeles, CA, on Friday, July 24, 2020. Funeral homes are claiming that bureaucratic delays in obtaining death certificates and disposition permits for burials and cremations, further increase family stress when grieving the death of a loved one, but impacts immigrant families even more, because it prevents families from returning their loved ones to their home countries. The group is announcing they will no longer remove Covid-19 bodies from hospitals, convalescents and hospices, until the issues are addressed by state and local agencies, including the Los Angeles Board of Supervisors. (Jay L. Clendenin / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: After Times investigation, Newsom says nursing home inspectors will be tested for coronavirus
item.dc:creator: Brittny Mejia, Jack Dolan, Phil Willon
item.description: The governor's promise came after a Times report that the state hadn't tested its health inspectors who regularly visit nursing homes and could unwittingly spread the virus.
item.content:encoded: The governor's promise came after a Times report that the state hadn't tested its health inspectors who regularly visit nursing homes and could unwittingly spread the virus.

media:content.media:description: RESEDA, CA - MARCH 25: A worker at Eisenberg Village nursing home screens all incoming for symptoms of the coronavirus on Wednesday, March 25, 2020 in Reseda, CA. (Jason Armond / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California, other states 'are essentially three New Yorks,' White House's Birx says
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth, Rong-Gong Lin II
item.description: White House COVID-19 advisor Dr. Deborah Birx compares California's surge to what New York experienced during the early days of the pandemic.
item.content:encoded: White House COVID-19 advisor Dr. Deborah Birx compares California's surge to what New York experienced during the early days of the pandemic.

media:content.media:description: TUSTIN, CA - JULY 22: Beauty technicians wear face masks as they give clients wearing face masks manicures and pedicures outdoors, as mandated by Gov. Newsom on Monday, in front of their Ritz Nails business at The District Tustin Legacy in Tustin Wednesday, July 22, 2020. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California workplace safety rules are likely to change due to coronavirus fears
item.dc:creator: Melody Gutierrez
item.description: Legislators have proposed expanding workers' compensation eligibility so that more employees will be covered if they are diagnosed with COVID-19, increasing the number of sick days for food service workers and requiring employers to pay a portion of utility and internet bills for teleworkers.
item.content:encoded: Legislators have proposed expanding workers' compensation eligibility so that more employees will be covered if they are diagnosed with COVID-19, increasing the number of sick days for food service workers and requiring employers to pay a portion of utility and internet bills for teleworkers.

media:content.media:description: Portland became the fourth city to mandate employers provide sick leave to workers. Worker rights advocates have pushed for such measures in several U.S. cities. Above, activists rally in January at New York's City Hall for paid sick leave.

item.title: USC's former campus gynecologist pleads not guilty to new felony charges
item.dc:creator: City News Service
item.description: The new charges involve alleged crimes against five women between 2011 and 2015, according to the Los Angeles County District Attorney's Office.
item.content:encoded: The new charges involve alleged crimes against five women between 2011 and 2015, according to the Los Angeles County District Attorney's Office.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JULY 24: George Tyndall, right, USC's former longtime campus gynecologist, confers with attorney Leonard Levine, left, in Los Angeles Superior Court with where Tyndall's arraignment was postponed on Friday, July 24, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. Prosecutors have added charges involving five new alleged victims since he was first charged last year. (Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Parents of missing Madera 2-year-old are arrested on suspicion of murder
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: Thaddeus Sran was reported missing from a Madera, Calif., residence on July 15.
item.content:encoded: Thaddeus Sran was reported missing from a Madera, Calif., residence on July 15.

media:content.media:description: The parents of 2-year-old Thaddeus Sran, who was reported missing in Madera last week, were arrested Friday on suspicion of murder, according to the Madera Police Department.

item.title: Progress reported against two major wildfires burning in Northern California
item.dc:creator: Jake Sheridan
item.description: The Hog and Gold fires combined have burned more than 28,000 acres in Lassen County. Almost 4,000 fire personnel are helping to battle the blazes.
item.content:encoded: The Hog and Gold fires combined have burned more than 28,000 acres in Lassen County. Almost 4,000 fire personnel are helping to battle the blazes.

media:content.media:description: Smoke from the Hog Fire is seen from Highway 36 west of Susanville, California, on Sunday, July 19, 2020. Mandatory evacuations are in effect for the Hog Fire which has grown to 9 square miles (23 square kilometers) in Lassen County. Cal Fire says about 170 structures are threatened.(Anjeanette Damon/The Reno Gazette-Journal via AP)

item.title: Coronavirus is killing more Californians than ever before, and cruel inequities are worsening
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II, Sean Greene, Priscella Vega
item.description: Californians of color are far more likely to become infected or die from the coronavirus. The most recent surge in cases exacerbates those inequities.
item.content:encoded: Californians of color are far more likely to become infected or die from the coronavirus. The most recent surge in cases exacerbates those inequities.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JULY 08: Testing continues Wednesday July 8, 2020 at Dodgers Stadium as drivers with an appointment continue in the queue for Coronavirus Covid-19 testing which has resumed at Dodger Stadium this week with a new drive-through testing. Dodger Stadium on Wednesday, July 8, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: LAPD officer, a 13-year veteran, dies after contracting coronavirus
item.dc:creator: James Queally, Kevin Rector
item.description: Officer Valentin Martinez is the second LAPD employee to die of the virus. Earlier this month, senior detention officer Erica McAdoo died.
item.content:encoded: Officer Valentin Martinez is the second LAPD employee to die of the virus. Earlier this month, senior detention officer Erica McAdoo died.

media:content.media:description: If contract is approved, LAPD officers would get an 8.2% raise over four years.

item.title: Column One: The apartment was ready in February. Four months later, the homeless man moved in
item.dc:creator: Doug Smith
item.description: One homeless man's four-month wait for an apartment, while it lay vacant, reflects a persistent failing of L.A.'s countywide system to get homeless people into housing â an especially critical need during the coronavirus pandemic.
item.content:encoded: One homeless man's four-month wait for an apartment, while it lay vacant, reflects a persistent failing of L.A.'s countywide system to get homeless people into housing â an especially critical need during the coronavirus pandemic.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA -JULY23: Terrance Whitten in his studio at his new apartment in Los Angeles. Whitten was homeless and living in Pan Pacific Park in February when The People Concern matched to an empty apartment in Eagle Rock. Four months of bureaucracy later, he moved into the apartment, which has remained vacant since then. Teague Terrace Apartments on Thursday, July 23, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Irfan Khan/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: With coronavirus surging, California workplaces come under greater scrutiny
item.dc:creator: Luke Money, Alejandra Reyes-Velarde, Paul Sisson
item.description: Community spread of COVID-19 is occurring in many areas, but officials have been particularly concerned about workers getting sick at their places of business and then infecting others at home.
item.content:encoded: Community spread of COVID-19 is occurring in many areas, but officials have been particularly concerned about workers getting sick at their places of business and then infecting others at home.

media:content.media:description: COLTON, CA - APRIL 09: Julie Montez, right, reacts as a nurse administers a coronavirus COVID-19 test at Arrowhead Regional Hospital public testing drive-through in Colton, CA. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Raccoon escapes unscathed from Riverside County jail
item.dc:creator: Alejandra Reyes-Velarde
item.description: A raccoon trapped in barbed wire at a Riverside County jail was rescued by animal services officers Thursday. The masked bandit was uninjured and released back into the wild.
item.content:encoded: A raccoon trapped in barbed wire at a Riverside County jail was rescued by animal services officers Thursday. The masked bandit was uninjured and released back into the wild.

media:content.media:description: Kellsey Hoesman, an officer with the Riverside County Department of Animal Services, helped rescue a raccoon trapped in barb wire at a jail in Riverside County.
media:content.media:credit: Riverside County Department of Animal Services

item.content:encoded: La NiÃ±a typically means dry conditions across the southern U.S. and more hurricanes in the Caribbean

item.title: Schools may soon apply for waivers to reopen â but only with union support
item.dc:creator: Nina Agrawal
item.description: School districts that apply for the waivers must include letters of support from their unions, making it unlikely many public schools will qualify.
item.content:encoded: School districts that apply for the waivers must include letters of support from their unions, making it unlikely many public schools will qualify.

media:content.media:description: GLENDALE, CA - MAY 26: Student items are left as they were since March 13, 2020 in the second grade classroom of teacher Mrs Miranda at Cerritos Elementary School in Glendale. County school officials are considering that with a persisting coronavirus threat, K-12 campuses will try to reopen in the fall. New L.A. County guidelines offer a possible roadmap but it could get complicated and costly to confront the logistics of reopening at an actual school in the wake of Covid-19. Glendale on Tuesday, May 26, 2020 in Glendale, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Ventura County passes 6,000 positive coronavirus tests as outbreak hits nursing facility
item.dc:creator: Jake Sheridan
item.description: Ventura County health authorities said positive tests have quadrupled over six weeks. At least 31 staffers and residents have tested positive at Ventura's Victoria Care Center.
item.content:encoded: Ventura County health authorities said positive tests have quadrupled over six weeks. At least 31 staffers and residents have tested positive at Ventura's Victoria Care Center.

media:content.media:description: The coronavirus known as SARS-CoV-2, which causes the disease COVID-19, is isolated from a patient in the U.S.
media:content.media:credit: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious DiseasesâRocky Mountain Laboratories

item.title: Attorney for top L.A. County official accuses sheriff of defamation over Facebook Live comments
item.dc:creator: Alene Tchekmedyian
item.description: An attorney representing Los Angeles County's chief executive officer has accused Sheriff Alex Villanueva of defamation and threatened to take legal action against him over comments he made Wednesday on a live Facebook broadcast.
item.content:encoded: An attorney representing Los Angeles County's chief executive officer has accused Sheriff Alex Villanueva of defamation and threatened to take legal action against him over comments he made Wednesday on a live Facebook broadcast.

media:content.media:description: MONTEREY PARK, CA-DECEMBER 3, 2018: Alex Villanueva, the new Los Angeles County Sheriff, looks towards his wife Vivian, during his swearing in ceremony at East Los Angeles College in Monterey Park on December 3, 2018. Villanueva became the 33rd Sheriff of Los Angeles County. (Mel Melcon/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Man and woman killed in Baldwin Park shooting
item.dc:creator: Alejandra Reyes-Velarde
item.description: Detectives are at the scene investigating the shooting death of a man and woman.
item.content:encoded: Detectives are at the scene investigating the shooting death of a man and woman.

media:content.media:description: Detectives are investigating after a man and woman were found fatally shot in Baldwin Park.

item.title: California prisons must set aside space for COVID-19 patients, judge orders
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton
item.description: At least 100 beds must be set aside at all 35 state prisons to handle potential COVID-19 outbreaks, a federal judge ruled.
item.content:encoded: At least 100 beds must be set aside at all 35 state prisons to handle potential COVID-19 outbreaks, a federal judge ruled.

media:content.media:description: San Quentin State Prison, opened in 1852 on the shore of San Francisco Bay, is the state's oldest prison and home to California's only death row.

item.title: California Legislature will let some lawmakers vote remotely amid COVID-19 pandemic
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy, John Myers
item.description: California Assembly plans to allow proxy voting by members particularly at risk from the coronavirus when the Legislature returns to session.
item.content:encoded: California Assembly plans to allow proxy voting by members particularly at risk from the coronavirus when the Legislature returns to session.

media:content.media:description: The California Assembly casts votes on Thursday, Sept. 12, 2019 at the state Capitol in Sacramento.

item.title: UC Davis researcher accused of hiding ties to Chinese military is hiding in consulate, U.S. says
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: A UC Davis cancer researcher, suspected of being a clandestine member of the Chinese military, has taken refuge in the Chinese consulate in San Francisco, according to U.S. prosecutors.
item.content:encoded: A UC Davis cancer researcher, suspected of being a clandestine member of the Chinese military, has taken refuge in the Chinese consulate in San Francisco, according to U.S. prosecutors.

media:content.media:description: Juan Tang

item.title: DNA solves Orange County's oldest cold case, identifying Jane Doe and suspected killer
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: 52 years after the body of a woman was found near a Huntington Beach field, Jane Doe and the man who authorities say killed her have been named.
item.content:encoded: 52 years after the body of a woman was found near a Huntington Beach field, Jane Doe and the man who authorities say killed her have been named.

media:content.media:description: Jane Doe, now known as Anita Louise Piteau, and her suspected killer, Johnny Chrisco, have been identified after 52 years.

item.title: Ask a Reporter: Erika Smith and Ben Oreskes on covering California
item.description: Join us Tuesday, July 28, for a live video event with L.A. Times columnist Erika Smith and reporter Ben Oreskes. They'll answer your questions about reporting on California and Los Angeles.
item.content:encoded: Join us Tuesday, July 28, for a live video event with L.A. Times columnist Erika Smith and reporter Ben Oreskes. They'll answer your questions about reporting on California and Los Angeles.

media:content.media:credit: Ask a Reporter is the L.A. Times' weekly live chat with a reporter about their job.

item.title: Whittier man dies after entering residence during termite fumigation
item.dc:creator: TomÃ¡s Mier
item.description: A fumigation company found the man's body inside the tented home.
item.content:encoded: A fumigation company found the man's body inside the tented home.

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles County Sheriff's deputies make entry into a home in the 11500 block of See Drive in Whittier, where a man was found dead Tuesday after entering his own home while it was being fumigated for termites.

item.title: California coronavirus deaths top 8,000 after record-high day

item.description: Single-day coronavirus infections and total hospitalizations also hit new highs in California after a record-high 157 fatalities Wednesday.
item.content:encoded: Single-day coronavirus infections and total hospitalizations also hit new highs in California after a record-high 157 fatalities Wednesday.

media:content.media:description: MISSION HILLS, CA - JULY 10: Nurses Janil Wise (CQ), left, and Melinda Gruman, right, talk over testing options for a patient who is pregnant and was exposed to a person with COVID-19, in the OB triage tent at Providence Holy Cross Medical Center on Friday, July 10, 2020 in Mission Hills, CA. (Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Officials identify 25-year-old man fatally shot after Ladera Heights house party
item.dc:creator: TomÃ¡s Mier
item.description: Officials identify 25-year-old man shot and killed during Ladera Heights house party
item.content:encoded: Officials identify 25-year-old man shot and killed during Ladera Heights house party

media:content.media:description: An investigation is underway in Ladera Heights, where a man in his 20s was shot and killed after leaving a house party late Wednesday night, July 22, 2020. The victim was at the party near the 5800 block of Holt Avenue when he got into argument with another person, the Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department said in a news release.

item.title: Better than social distancing? In this game you take a virtual walk in Griffith Park
item.dc:creator: Todd Martens
item.description: "Four Months Earlier," a game equivalent of a COVID-era tone poem, takes us back to the days we could walk L.A.'s Griffith Park with an out-of-towner.
item.content:encoded: "Four Months Earlier," a game equivalent of a COVID-era tone poem, takes us back to the days we could walk L.A.'s Griffith Park with an out-of-towner.

item.title: Goodbye, guy on a horse. A new wave of monument design is changing how we honor history
item.dc:creator: Carolina A. Miranda
item.description: Shouldn't public monuments have public input? In the George Floyd moment, artists and designers are changing the nature of monuments and the histories they honor.
item.content:encoded: Shouldn't public monuments have public input? In the George Floyd moment, artists and designers are changing the nature of monuments and the histories they honor.

media:content.media:description: A new statue in Bristol, England, portrays Jen Reid.

item.title: You see the warnings everywhere. But does Prop. 65 really protect you?
item.dc:creator: Geoffrey Mohan
item.description: The profusion of warnings stemming from California's landmark consumer safety law has left shoppers overwarned, underinformed and potentially unprotected, a Times investigation has found.
item.content:encoded: The profusion of warnings stemming from California's landmark consumer safety law has left shoppers overwarned, underinformed and potentially unprotected, a Times investigation has found.

item.title: LAPD begins cost cutting, and units must 'show your relevance,' chief says
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector, Richard Winton, Cindy Chang
item.description: Following a historic $150-million cut to its budget, the LAPD pushes forward with internal changes in anticipation of an even broader shake-up.
item.content:encoded: Following a historic $150-million cut to its budget, the LAPD pushes forward with internal changes in anticipation of an even broader shake-up.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIF. -- MONDAY, JANUARY 28, 2019: LAPD Chief Michel Moore announces that for the first time in five years, violent crime was down in Los Angeles in 2018, with the number of homicides on track to be among the lowest in more than 50 years during a press conference at LAPD headquarters in Los Angeles, Calif., on Jan. 28, 2019. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times

item.title: Sierra Club reflects on its racist roots and looks toward a new future
item.dc:creator: Susanne Rust, Bettina Boxall, Rosanna Xia
item.description: John Muir, a towering figure among environmentalists, made harmful and disparaging remarks about Native Americans and Black people.
item.content:encoded: John Muir, a towering figure among environmentalists, made harmful and disparaging remarks about Native Americans and Black people.

media:content.media:description: Theodore Roosevelt stands with conservationist John Muir on Glacier Point in Yosemite. Roosevelt is considered a pioneer in presidential image-crafting.

item.title: California was impatient. Now it tops New York for most coronavirus cases
item.dc:creator: Luke Money, James Rainey
item.description: California topped New York in coronavirus cases. What is unknown is if the Golden State is on a path to have its hospitals overwhelmed
item.content:encoded: California topped New York in coronavirus cases. What is unknown is if the Golden State is on a path to have its hospitals overwhelmed

media:content.media:description: CARSON, CA - APRIL 28, 2020 - - Carson residents Kaeli Burks, 3, left, and her cousin Bailey Watson, 5, look out the window of their car after their mothers helped them with self-testing at a new drive-up testing site for COVID-19 outside the East Wing of the Congresswoman Juanita Millender-McDonald Community Center in Carson on April 28, 2020. Free COVID-19 testing is available to all city residents thanks to a partnership between the city and US Health Fairs. Carson is the first Southern California city to offer free testing to all its residents. Mayor Albert Robles and members of the City Council will be joined by Assemblyman Mike A. Gipson, D-Carson, for the test site opening. (Genaro Molina/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Workers fear returning to work. Many are resisting the call
item.dc:creator: Margot Roosevelt, Hugo MartÃ­n, Taylor Avery
item.description: Many, especially those backed by labor unions, push back against returning to their workplaces, citing employers' failures to prevent COVID-19 outbreaks.
item.content:encoded: Many, especially those backed by labor unions, push back against returning to their workplaces, citing employers' failures to prevent COVID-19 outbreaks.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JULY 08: Hotel workers protest for their safety in front of the InterContinental Los Angeles Downtown on Wednesday, July 8, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. A spokesperson said a survey of hospitality workers found that the lack of safety measures such as having hand sanitizer, gloves and companies' lack of enforcing social distancing rules, were risking the workers' health. The spokesperson added that given the choice between saving the economy or saving their families, they'll save their families. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: As big leagues prepare to return amid pandemic, memories of when barrio baseball ruled East L.A.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Baxter
item.description: After World War II, a loose affiliation of amateur and semiprofessional teams played nearly every weekend throughout Southern California and northern Mexico. Nowhere were those games bigger than in East L.A.
item.content:encoded: After World War II, a loose affiliation of amateur and semiprofessional teams played nearly every weekend throughout Southern California and northern Mexico. Nowhere were those games bigger than in East L.A.

media:content.media:description: SAN DIMAS, CALIFORNIA JULY 22, 2020-Conrad Munatones goes through some old photos at his home in San Dimas. Munatones was in the Dodgers organization as a catcher before becoming a teacher. (Wally Skalij/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Violence breaks out at the Azerbaijan Consulate in Brentwood as protesters clash

item.title: No answers yet in ongoing investigation into San Gabriel Mission fire

item.description: A definitive cause for a fire that tore through the San Gabriel Mission on a recent early morning remains under investigation.
item.content:encoded: A definitive cause for a fire that tore through the San Gabriel Mission on a recent early morning remains under investigation.

media:content.media:description: SAN GABRIEL, CALIFORNIA-JULY 11, 2020-The 249-year-old San Gabriel Mission caught fire overnight and burned most of the roof and interior. The cause is unknown at this time.(Carolyn Cole/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Orange County indie label Burger Records shuts down amid sexual misconduct allegations

(Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

Officials reported 2,848 newly confirmed COVID-19 cases on Sunday as hospitalizations have reached a new high. (Dania Maxwell / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Judge orders release of vulnerable inmates at Lompoc prisons hit by virus
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton
item.description: The Bureau of Prisons is ordered to draw up a list of vulnerable inmates to release from Lompoc federal prisons as part of an ACLU COVID-19 lawsuit.
item.content:encoded: The Bureau of Prisons is ordered to draw up a list of vulnerable inmates to release from Lompoc federal prisons as part of an ACLU COVID-19 lawsuit.

media:content.media:description: The Federal Correctional Institution in Lompoc, Calif., is shown in a Dec. 1995 photo. The prison, which houses low to medium security inmates, is on the same grounds as the Lompoc Federal Prison Camp, where former Gov., Fife Symington would likely serve his sentence. Symington resigned in disgrace Sept. 3, 1997, after a federal jury convicted him of defrauding lenders during his former career as a real estate developer. ( AP Photo/Santa Maria Times, Jeffrey May)

item.title: CSU undergrads must take an ethnic studies or social justice class starting in 2023
item.dc:creator: Nina Agrawal
item.description: CSU is requiring ethnic studies, the first addition to its general education requirements in 40 years. But the change was not without controversy.
item.content:encoded: CSU is requiring ethnic studies, the first addition to its general education requirements in 40 years. But the change was not without controversy.

media:content.media:description: Kyla Artigo, 20, center, speaks during an Asian American studies class at Cal State Long Beach.

item.title: Marciano Art Foundation settles with employees laid off during union drive
item.dc:creator: Carolina A. Miranda
item.description: The Marciano laid off 70 visitor services staffers when the museum shut its galleries in 2019. AFSCME called the layoffs "an anti-union tactic."
item.content:encoded: The Marciano laid off 70 visitor services staffers when the museum shut its galleries in 2019. AFSCME called the layoffs "an anti-union tactic."

media:content.media:description: Laid off workers, who had been attempting to unionize, picket the Marciano Art Foundation on the morning of Friday, Nov. 8, 2019. The protesters included several dozen laid off visitor services workers along with supporters and organizers from the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees (AFSCME). The workers had been attempting to unionize.
media:content.media:credit: Carolina A. Miranda / Los Angeles Times

item.title: Citing racist past, Hawthorne elementary school drops Peter Burnett name
item.dc:creator: Jake Sheridan
item.description: Wiseburn Unified School District trustees vote to remove the name of California's controversial first elected governor from Peter Burnett Elementary.
item.content:encoded: Wiseburn Unified School District trustees vote to remove the name of California's controversial first elected governor from Peter Burnett Elementary.

media:content.media:description: HAWTHORNE, CA - JULY 16, 2020. Wiseburn Unified School District Superintendent Blake Silvers stands in front a sign where the name of former California Gov.Peter Burnett has been covered with black plastic and duct tape. Peter Burnett Elementary School in Hawthorne has temporaily changed its name to 138th Street School after community members complained that Burnett committed violence against Black, Indigenous and Chinese people. (Luis Sinco / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: FBI links killing of California lawyer to suspect in deadly attack on New Jersey judge's family
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton
item.description: FBI links So Cal lawyer's murder to suspect in deadly attack on New Jersey judge's family
item.content:encoded: FBI links So Cal lawyer's murder to suspect in deadly attack on New Jersey judge's family

media:content.media:description: New York State Police block off a road near the scene where the body of Roy Den Hollander was found on Monday, July 20, 2020 near Livingston Manor, N.Y. Hollander, a self-described "anti-feminist" lawyer found dead in the Catskills of an apparent self-inflicted gunshot wound, is being investigated as the possible gunman in the shooting of a federal judge's family in New Jersey. (Jim Sabastian/The Times Herald-Record via AP)

item.title: 8th death row inmate dies at San Quentin as COVID-19 surge continues in prison
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: The death brings the total to 13 among prisoners at the Marin County facility.
item.content:encoded: The death brings the total to 13 among prisoners at the Marin County facility.

media:content.media:description: Razor wire encircles the exercise yard at San Quentin. Federal courts have ruled that it is unconstitutional to execute people who are not aware of what is happening to them

item.title: Parents rush to hire tutors and create learning pods. But not everyone has options
item.dc:creator: Sonali Kohli, Nina Agrawal
item.description: Frantic parents with resources are rushing to hire tutors and form learning pods to bring distance learning to their homes and backyards amid coronavirus school closures.
item.content:encoded: Frantic parents with resources are rushing to hire tutors and form learning pods to bring distance learning to their homes and backyards amid coronavirus school closures.

media:content.media:description: EL SERENO, CA - JULY 16, 2020: Left top right-Luna Tringale, 6, her sister Anaya Tringale, 5, father Rolando Tringale, 40, and mother Kamren Curiel, 41, are photographed in outdoor classroom, located in backyard of their home in El Sereno. Luna is a 2nd grader and Anaya is a kindergartner at Aldama Elementary School in Highland Park. When school resumes next month, all classes will be taught online because of the coronavirus outbreak. (Mel Melcon / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California has most COVID-19 cases in U.S., surpassing New York, as spike continues
item.dc:creator: Luke Money

item.content:encoded: Newsom reports that 12,807 new coronavirus infections have been reported in the past 24 hours â a record high â bringing the state's total to 413,576.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JULY 08: EMT Leticia Jimenez delivers the testing kit to drivers during drive through Coronavirus Covid-19 testing in LA County at the Charles R. Drew University of Medicine and Science in South Los Angeles on July 8, 2020 as California records its highest single-day coronavirus death toll with 149 fatalities reported. The Charles R. Drew University site has tested a large number of people from racial and ethnic minority groups that are at higher risk for poor outcomes and complications from COVID-19. Drew University on Wednesday, July 8, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Strong evidence quake faults run through site of Hollywood skyscrapers, state says
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II, Lorena IÃ±iguez Elebee
item.description: The California Geological Survey also indicates limitations in previous studies cited by Hollywood Center developers as evidence of the absence of a fault.
item.content:encoded: The California Geological Survey also indicates limitations in previous studies cited by Hollywood Center developers as evidence of the absence of a fault.

item.title: Sierra Club calls out the racism of John Muir
item.dc:creator: Shelby Grad
item.description: The Sierra Club acknowledges the racist history of its co-founder, the famed environmentalist John Muir.
item.content:encoded: The Sierra Club acknowledges the racist history of its co-founder, the famed environmentalist John Muir.

media:content.media:description: Theodore Roosevelt (1858 - 1919) (left), the twenty-sixth President of the United States, with the Scottish born American conservationist John Muir (1838 - 1914) on Glacier Point in Yosemite, California. (Photo by MPI/Getty Images)

item.title: 'I'm going to die out here.' Brutal heat is even more dangerous with coronavirus
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Lai
item.description: Sweltering heat is not new to the Inland Empire's homeless population. But the threat of coronavirus is.
item.content:encoded: Sweltering heat is not new to the Inland Empire's homeless population. But the threat of coronavirus is.

media:content.media:description: INDIO, CA - JULY 15: Osmani Ramirez, 41, who has been homeless for 4 years, tries to shield himself from the blazing sun and 109-degree heat as he walks in to the cooling station at Martha's Village & Kitchen, one of the largest providers of homeless services in the Coachella Valley and Riverside County. The homeless and homeless shelters in Indio and Coachella Valley already face hardships this time of year when the area heats up to 100+ degree weather. Shelters already struggle to care for the homeless, but now COVID exacerbated their struggles. Photo taken Wednesday, July 15, 2020 in Indio, CA. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California feared pandemic would overwhelm Medicaid, but that hasn't happened. Why?
item.dc:creator: Rachel Bluth, Angela Hart
item.description: "It's a mystery," says one expert. Some 2 million Californians were projected to join Medi-Cal, the state's insurance program for low-income people.
item.content:encoded: "It's a mystery," says one expert. Some 2 million Californians were projected to join Medi-Cal, the state's insurance program for low-income people.

media:content.media:description: Vanessa Poveda lost her health insurance after losing her job as a server at a San Francisco gastropub. She thinks she probably qualifies for Medi-Cal but hasn't signed up yet, in part because the task feels daunting.

item.title: LAPD promised to curb violence on protesters for two decades, but has yet to deliver
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector
item.description: The LAPD is being sued for violence against protesters â again. The department committed to policy changes after incidents in 2000 and 2007.
item.content:encoded: The LAPD is being sued for violence against protesters â again. The department committed to policy changes after incidents in 2000 and 2007.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 02: LAPD officers roll up Cahuenga Blvd toward Hollywood Blvd in Hollywood to control protestors made of mostly students as they marched Tuesday afternoon to protest the death of George Floyd during an arrest in Minneapolis last week. The group gathered at the intersection of Hollywood Blvd and Vine Street for a peaceful demonstration and marched through parts of Hollywood encountering LAPD officers and National Guardsmen. Hollywood on Tuesday, June 2, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 'I don't believe it': Huntington Beach a symbol of mask resistance as doubters abound
item.dc:creator: Jake Sheridan
item.description: As infection rates soar in Orange County, residents of Surf City doubt the severity of the pandemic and call for easing restrictions.
item.content:encoded: As infection rates soar in Orange County, residents of Surf City doubt the severity of the pandemic and call for easing restrictions.

media:content.media:description: HUNTINGTON BEACH, CALIFORNIA JULY 17, 2020-Pedestrians walk along the strand in Huntington Beach as Orange County deals with a surge in the cornavirus. (Wally Skalij/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Inmates talk of COVID fear and helplessness after transfers bring 'the beast' to San Quentin
item.dc:creator: Kim Christensen, Richard Winton
item.description: Inmates said they felt helpless as coronavirus swept rapidly through California's prisons.
item.content:encoded: Inmates said they felt helpless as coronavirus swept rapidly through California's prisons.

media:content.media:description: Chino, CA, Tuesday, July 21, 2020 - Outside the California Institute for Men, Chino. The Chino prison reported more than 600 cases of COVID-19 and nine deaths. The 700 inmates selected for transfer had medical conditions that made them especially vulnerable to the virus. (Robert Gauthier / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Flaring at Wilmington refinery caused by mechanical failure
item.dc:creator: Alejandra Reyes-Velarde
item.description: Community members complained of flaring and black smoke coming from the Phillips 66 refinery in Wilmington. Officials say the flaring was caused by a mechanical failure.
item.content:encoded: Community members complained of flaring and black smoke coming from the Phillips 66 refinery in Wilmington. Officials say the flaring was caused by a mechanical failure.

media:content.media:description: WILMINGTON, CA -- TUESDAY, MARCH 1, 2016 -- The Phillips 66 refinery looms over a Wilmington neighborhood where some long-time residents feel their health issues might stem from their proximity to the refinery. The Union Oil Company of California built the original refinery in 1919 between the old Anaheim road and the port, years before homes were constructed to form the neighborhood. ( Rick Loomis / Los Angeles Times )

item.title: Former L.A. City Councilman Hal Bernson dies at 89
item.dc:creator: Dakota Smith
item.description: Hal Bernson, who represented the northwest San Fernando Valley, fought for seismic safety laws in earthquake-prone L.A.
item.content:encoded: Hal Bernson, who represented the northwest San Fernando Valley, fought for seismic safety laws in earthquake-prone L.A.

media:content.media:description: Hal Bernson, Los Angeles city councilman.
media:content.media:credit: Harold Examiner Collection Los Angeles Public Library

item.title: Reopening plans at UC Berkeley, other campuses fall apart amid coronavirus surge
item.dc:creator: Teresa Watanabe
item.description: Plans to begin the fall semester with some in-person classes are being shelved at UC Berkeley, UC Merced, Pomona, Occidental and other schools.
item.content:encoded: Plans to begin the fall semester with some in-person classes are being shelved at UC Berkeley, UC Merced, Pomona, Occidental and other schools.

media:content.media:description: A group of students walk through the Sather Gate at UC Berkeley.

item.title: Calabasas mayor calls out YouTuber Jake Paul for house party, sets new restrictions
item.dc:creator: Jake Sheridan
item.description: As the coronavirus crisis rages on, the Calabasas mayor calls out YouTube personality Jake Paul for throwing a massive house party as she issued new COVID restrictions.
item.content:encoded: As the coronavirus crisis rages on, the Calabasas mayor calls out YouTube personality Jake Paul for throwing a massive house party as she issued new COVID restrictions.

media:content.media:description: Jake Paul arrives at the Teen Choice Awards at the Galen Center on Sunday, Aug. 13, 2017, in Los Angeles. (Photo by Jordan Strauss/Invision/AP)

item.title: At SoCal's drive-in concerts, fans, artists and promoters make the best of a live-music apocalypse
item.dc:creator: August Brown
item.description: With traditional live-music gatherings prohibited because of COVID-19, drive-in concerts have emerged as a safe, socially distant, better-than-nothing alternative.
item.content:encoded: With traditional live-music gatherings prohibited because of COVID-19, drive-in concerts have emerged as a safe, socially distant, better-than-nothing alternative.

media:content.media:description: VENTURA, CA - JULY 18: Concert goers listen to Ozomatli at Concerts In Your Car - Fishbone, Ozomatli and Rey Fresco at the Ventura County Fairgrounds on Saturday, July 18, 2020 in Ventura, CA. This is one of the first legal returns to live music in SoCal since COVID-19, at a 700-capacity drive-in concert where patrons will watch in their vehicles and listen over FM radio. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Restaurant spurs uproar and risks being closed down for defying virus orders
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: A Northern California restaurant has caused an uproar for dismissing county orders to practice COVID-19 safety protocols.
item.content:encoded: A Northern California restaurant has caused an uproar for dismissing county orders to practice COVID-19 safety protocols.

item.title: Ex-Laguna Beach officer held gun to colleague's head after bar-hopping, prosecutors say
item.dc:creator: Chace Beech
item.description: The 35-year-old is facing one felony count of assault with a deadly weapon.
item.content:encoded: The 35-year-old is facing one felony count of assault with a deadly weapon.

item.title: FBI investigates whether suspect in judge family attack is behind California lawyer's slaying
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton
item.description: FBI is looking into whether the killing of a men's rights attorney in San Bernardino County is tied to a deadly attack on a New Jersey judge's family.
item.content:encoded: FBI is looking into whether the killing of a men's rights attorney in San Bernardino County is tied to a deadly attack on a New Jersey judge's family.

media:content.media:description: New York State Police block off a road near the scene where the body of Roy Den Hollander was found on Monday, July 20, 2020 near Livingston Manor, N.Y. Hollander, a self-described "anti-feminist" lawyer found dead in the Catskills of an apparent self-inflicted gunshot wound, is being investigated as the possible gunman in the shooting of a federal judge's family in New Jersey. (Jim Sabastian/The Times Herald-Record via AP)

item.title: Little noticed, Filipino Americans are dying of COVID-19 at an alarming rate
item.dc:creator: Tiffany Wong
item.description: Filipino Americans are dying of coronavirus infection at higher rates, revealing issues in public health treatment and healthcare for Asian Americans.
item.content:encoded: Filipino Americans are dying of coronavirus infection at higher rates, revealing issues in public health treatment and healthcare for Asian Americans.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIFORNIA JULY 18, 2020-USC professor Adrian De Leon sits in fornt of a mural in Filipinotown area of Los Angeles. DeLeon is currently looking at ways the pandemic affects Americans across racial and socioeconomic lines. (Wally Skalij/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Orange County now has second-worst coronavirus outbreak in California
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: COVID-19 cases in Orange County reach 29,986, just ahead of Riverside County's 29,983. Only L.A. County, with about 160,000 infections, has more.
item.content:encoded: COVID-19 cases in Orange County reach 29,986, just ahead of Riverside County's 29,983. Only L.A. County, with about 160,000 infections, has more.

media:content.media:description: NEWPORT BEACH, CA - JULY 20: People walk and skateboard on the sidewalk past businesses on a summer day Monday, July 20, 2020 in Newport Beach, CA. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Wearing masks could help you avoid major illness even if you get coronavirus, experts say
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II
item.description: Skeptics say: Why wear masks if they don't filter out all coronavirus? Scientists say: Because it could mean less severe illness.
item.content:encoded: Skeptics say: Why wear masks if they don't filter out all coronavirus? Scientists say: Because it could mean less severe illness.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JULY 19, 2020 - - People, wearing masks against the coronavirus, shop along Alvarado Street in MacArthur Park in Los Angeles on July 19, 2020. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)
